qas.question: In what year were big changes made to the ANSI?
What did the 1960 changes to film speed measures lead to?

answers.text: effectively doubling the nominal speed of many black-and-white negative films

qas.question: Which other system were these changes applied to?
In what year was the BS system modified?
What safety factors were done away with beginning with the modifications to the standards?
When were new safety factors put in place?
The nominal speed of what films were halved by abandoning safety factors?
When were changes applied to the DIN system?
The Ilford HP3 changes were applied to what in the following years?

context: The ASA standard underwent a major revision in <a0_0><b5_0>1960<b5_0/><a0_0/> with ASA PH2.5-1960, when the method to determine film speed was refined and previously applied <a4_0>safety factors against under-exposure<a4_0/> were abandoned, <a1_0>effectively doubling the nominal speed of many <b6_0>black-and-white negative<b6_0/> films<a1_0/>. For example, an Ilford HP3 that had been rated at <b7_0>200 ASA<b7_0/> <b8_0>before 1960<b8_0/> was labeled 400 ASA afterwards without any change to the emulsion. Similar changes were applied to <a2_0><b9_0>the DIN system<b9_0/><a2_0/> with DIN 4512:1961-10 and the BS system with BS 1380:<a3_0>1963<a3_0/> in the following years.
